thread.title: Taxi drivers threaten strikes over Uber
thread.title_full: Taxi drivers threaten strikes over Uber | Business Spectator

author: AAP
title: Taxi drivers threaten strikes over Uber
text:
Taxi drivers are threatening to ramp up their protest against Uber with rolling strikes.
More than 400 drivers rallied on the steps of Victoria's parliament on Thursday calling on the Victorian government to do more to clamp down on the illegal ride-sharing service.
Until something is done, taxi drivers will take part in rolling strikes across the country starting next week, the rally which blocked a major Melbourne street was told.
"We won't say what day, but it could be at the airport or in Melbourne's CBD," Victorian TaxiIn Families spokesman David Singh told the crowd.
"It is a united cause. The government need to understand there are 150,000 drivers (Australia-wide) and families who are struggling."
Spring Street outside the Victorian parliament was clogged with taxies during the two-hour protest about midday, and drivers chanted "we want justice" and "shut down UberX".
Another VTF spokeswoman, Sandy Spanos, said Uber was undermining an industry that pumped $1.4 billion into state and federal coffers.
She questioned how the elderly and disabled would get around if taxis were to disappear.
"They don't have smart phones," she told the crowd.
Another elderly cab driver was overcome with emotion as he spoke.
He said, despite promises made by Premier Daniel Andrews to him personally, he was still waiting for a response on what the government would do about Uber.
"We work for it, for 50 years I have driven this taxi," the man told the crowd.
"None of these people with a taxi licence, none of their kids would take on their licence."
At the end of the rally, the cab drivers marched down empty tram tracks on Bourke Street.
Their protest coincided with a four-hour strike by Melbourne's tram drivers who are locked in an unresolved pay dispute with Yarra Trams.
